intro: Alkanna amplexicaulis, commonly known as the clasping alkanna, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its woolly, hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces striking red or orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its unique growth habit involves the leaves clasping the stem, giving it a distinctive appearance. Alkanna amplexicaulis is adapted to hot, dry environments and is often found in rocky soils.
